segments.text: recognized very happily.
They had no trouble at all.
Everybody got along fine.
Of course, they were very high types, really.
They were top people.
In the working of, let's say, drawings and record keepings and so forth, whose responsibilities were those after the plant closed down?
After the plant closed down?
Well, when the plant was built originally, Hercules had a contract.
that says that if indeed the plant is ever put up for sale, then Hercules would not bid on the plant, but they would have the opportunity to match the highest bidder.
So the upshot was, of course, that the plant did revert to Hercules after it was shut down.
Hearst bought a tremendous amount of stuff to Morgantown, wouldn't he?
He came to Morgantown as resource director after they shut it down.

bought an awful lot of the operating uh i might some of them may still be out there i don't know with charts and stuff like that but the the things that were really it was really too bad was that all these uh full-scale drawings of all the equipment was uh was thrown out how was it thrown out well this fellow they got this felt we had this administrative assistant like i say periodically in the government they used to say how many
how many cubic feet of file space you got, and then you tell them, they say, get rid of 30% of it.
So that was how you got rid of some of it.
You didn't say nothing to nobody.
Like I say, it was a body blow, but they were gone.
And those were the only existing copies of it?
I don't know what they had at Louisiana, very frankly.
I just don't know.
But see, at that time, the plant was shut down.
We found out a couple of things.
One, it was possible to duplicate
German equipment in this country.
We could build equipment.
But the thing that you had to remember was that we were about at the, it was almost impossible to scale that stuff up due to the wall thickness.
Due to the what?
Wall thickness of the vessels because of the tremendously high pressure.
See, those vessels were designed for 11,000 pound pressure.
And the only way that we could make the converters, they were actually, there was only one outfit in the country that could make them.
And that was messed up here in Pittsburgh.
And those converter bodies were actually forged on a mandrel.
You can't roll anything that small and that thick.
And of course, that was one of the big things against those kind of pressures.
See, we don't use those kind of pressures anymore.
We got away from them.
And one of the reasons we got away from them was that you just plain can't scale up those kind of vessels.
So, in other words, to expand the plant, to produce enough oil to be realistic would be too expensive?
Is that what you're saying?
Well, in the first place, yes, obviously, because we were off by a factor of five of what it would cost to make gasoline from oil, I would guess.
And I thought that was optimistic.
The process, the hydrogenation process, of course, at the time operated at 700 atmospheres.
and that required a very special type of equipment.
And like I say, it's almost impossible to scale up those type of vessels.
And then see, we had water and oil washes in the gas recycle system, which again recycled 700 atmospheres.
So we had a lot of real high-pressure vessels in that plant, and it was a relatively small plant.
The plant was only designed for about four ton of coal an hour, and we never got up to that.
Louisiana, Missouri plants produce monthly, or?
Well, that's hard to answer, but the aggregatewe produced over a million barrels of gasoline by coal hydrogenation.
And we made one three-month run.
And the product was shipped to Aberdeen Proving Ground?
Oh, shipped everywhere.
I'll never forget, Dr. Storch and I went to one of the Army posts
You found out they were using the damn stuff in garbage trucks, and that hurt his pride.
It was also used to fuel the Burlington Railroad.
We ran a, yeah, that's right, on dedication, we did run a train up to Louisiana, from St. Louis to Louisiana, Missouri, and back.
But we cheated a little bit on that.
And that was that we, we, we, we, uh, that gasoline was made by hydrogenating the coal
We were in a hurry for it.
They had scheduled this dedication before we were ready, and Hurst had no choice.
The only way he could make it was to run the vapor phase on our mineral, run the liquid phase on coal tar.
And later on we got into it.
See, it was a dual plan.
The first thing you did, you hydrogenated the coal to make what we called a metal oil.
And then you went over into another plant and hydrogenated the metal oil into gasoline.
Metal oil?
Middle oil.
Middle oil.
Middle oil.
Just a term.
I see.
But both of these plants operatedboth of them were designed to operate at 700 atmospheres.
10,500 pounds per hour?
10,500 pounds.
Yeah.
Hmm.
Did you have any problem with valves and this sort of thing?
Oh, yeah.
Yeah.
We hadwell, yeah, we had a lot of problems with valves because of the letdown and the
The way we got away from that pretty much was we went to silicon carbide on everything.
I mean, not silicon carbide, titanium carbide.
No, we'll get it right out.
Tungsten titanium carbide.
But like I say, it was pretty obvious to me as a mechanical engineer that a plant that operated those kinds of pressures even wellof course, the same thing was true of ammonia.
It just wasn't practical.
See, we couldn't scale up the ammonia plant.
We had five ammonia plants for about the best we ever got was 200 tons a day, and now they make 1,500 tons with one plant.
With the same process?
Well, it's the same process, except it operates at much lower pressure.
Instead of operating at 15,000 pounds, the ammonia plants now run at 3,200.
So...
The answer is that no process that has to go to those kind of pressures, to me at least, isn't practical.
I'm not all sure they're practical, lower pressures.
How many other Germans were involved besides these seven?
That's all I know of.
I see.
And they weren't treated badly?
They weren't... Oh, no, they were accepted just the same.
I mean, they were technical people.
I mean, they, you know, the wives went back and forth and had coffee and
We went down to St. Louis together and maybe see an operator.
So they were very rapidly, they just became a part of the community.

And like I say, one thing I've noticed, and I've spent a lot of time in Europe, and I've noticed that you will get people who will come together or get together on an intelligence level more than they will actually on a national level.
And, of course, I say these people were top people.
They were intelligent people, and they just put it right in.
How were these people chosen?
Did Dr. Hurst choose them?
Well, Hurst and Schroeder and a bunch of them went over.
That's why I was still in the service.
And I guess they went over and talked to these people.
They didn't put a gun on anybody, he said, you know, the ones that wanted to come, great.
Luckily, they were able to get to best.
Where does Mr. Sternberg fit into this?
I know he was with the Bureau of Mines.
Sternberg, let's see, I think he had charge of the lab back there, as I remember.
No, no, no, no, no, no, no.
He was on the, no, Sternberg was on the, he was on the technical reels and stuff like that.
type of thing.
So he was the one who was translating the German documents?
Yeah, I think I'm pretty sure he was, yeah.
Yeah, I mixed him up.
Tarpley had charge of the lab.
Are we okay?
Yeah.
But see, my job at first was, well, one of the things we had to do, we had to redesign the plant as far as high-pressure recycle compressors go.
And I handled that.
But we had already built up a group of people who could handle this high-pressure equipment.
They were holdovers from the ammonia plant.
So really, the only problems that they had were pretty much over in the hydrogenation area, as far as the hydrogenation goes.
The hydrogen manufacturing and compression and cleanup just ran pretty smoothly.
And like I say, we had plenty of spare equipment.
See, what we did, we had one process hyper, and then we had another hyper just sitting there, ready to go.
And then we had a third one that we used for inert gas.
But we didn't need that much inert gas.
Then later on, we bought another small compressor for inert gas, much lower flow, much lower power.
Most of the time we got by on one hyper.
Let me ask you, did you ever have an opportunity to talk to some of these German scientists and inquire how they felt about their synthetic program during the war and what problems they had?
Oh, yeah, yeah, that's what we used to do.
We used to sit around in the evening and maybe have a drink or two.
In fact, one of the things that theyI think it was, what was it, the name?
They couldn't get olives.
They couldn't get what?
They couldn't get olives in Germany.
But they were all martini drinkers.
All these Germans were.
And they introduced us to another type ofoh, I guess that was the first time I ever saw onions in martinis.
They had learned that in Germany, because they didn't have olives.
And lemons were kind of hard to come by, too.
They started the cocktail onion thing.
But anyway, no, I can say we sat around and talked.
Actually, the German synthetic fuel effort, at the most, was never more than about 400,000 barrels a day.
Roughly, they got half by synthetics and half from crude.
So they ran the war machine, you would say, about 50 percent?
Well, toward the end, of course, it was less, because they had a lot of planes and stuff sitting on the ground.
had a pretty high priority for the bombers, too.
Of course.
Did they imply that politics that, uh, hampered or favored their production during the war?
Um, yes, yes.
Of course, it was very, as you know, it was very political, and you had, well, actually, you had a maniac running the goddamn country.
So what could you expect?
So, no, he, he did everything.
He ran everything from the seat of his britches.
The upshot was that
even people like Speer, who had charge of everything under Hitler, was still frequently overruled by Hitler on things.
The hierarchy over there was Speer, I guess, who had everything, and then a fellow named Peer, who had all synthetics, and then Donath, who had coal hydrogenation.
He was head of the coal hydrogenation program.
He was the head guy we brought over.
Does the name Rowland sound familiar?
Who?
R-O-E-L-A-N-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-A-T-H-
H-L-E-N. Rowland?
No.
As a German scientist who was in charge, perhaps, under Donoff?
No, he wasn't.
We had nobody by that name, I reckon.
I couldn't remember.
Uh-huh.
No.
No.
Now, when time comes for the plant to be shut down, were you still around then?
Yeah, I was here.
I had moved back here and started at the
place at the station out here, I'd move back here and start a pressure gasification program.
Because my calculations show that we could make a tremendous saving in horsepower by generating either the hydrogen or the hydrogen plus CO and the elevated pressures.
And of course, a compressor curve is a logarithmic curve.
The pressure, I mean, the power varies as the logarithm of the pressure, not as the pressure.
So that says that the low pressures are where you use the most power.
So I started my program at 450 PSI, figuring at that time I'd made an awful lot of the potential savings, even if you went up, say, to 10,000 pounds.
And what was the reaction of the Bureau of Mines when they discovered the decision is to close the plant?
Well, the fine damn thing was to shut that thing off.
Thanks.
